title: How We Talk & Listen
description: Learn about your conversation patterns and listening styles.

questions.text: What's most important to me when we're having a conversation?
choices: That you remember what I say
That you put down your phone

therapeutic.rationale: Conversation needs vary significantly. Non-interruption seekers need verbal space; memory-seekers need evidence of listening; question-askers need curiosity shown; phone-downers need full presence. When our primary conversation need goes unmet, we feel unheard even when our partner is trying to listen.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conversation needs mean different things signal 'listening' to each of you. The memory-seeker needs their words retained; the question-asker needs engagement. Show listening in your partner's language.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conversation needs mean you'll naturally make each other feel heard. You both want the same thing from conversations.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel truly listened to? What signals do you look for? Does your partner know what you need during conversations?

questions.text: How do I prefer to give you feedback or criticism?

therapeutic.rationale: Feedback delivery reveals how we handle interpersonal tension. Gentle/indirect protects feelings but may be missed; direct/kind prioritizes clarity; humor diffuses tension; careful wording prevents harm. Understanding your partner's natural feedback style helps you receive it even when delivered imperfectly.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different feedback styles can cause miscommunication. The indirect giver's hints may be missed by the direct receiver; the humor-user's feedback may not be taken seriously. Learn to recognize feedback in your partner's style.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared feedback styles mean criticism will be delivered and received as intended. You speak the same feedback language.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you naturally give feedback? Does your partner receive it well? What happens when you have something difficult to say?

questions.text: What's my preferred listening style when you share problems?

therapeutic.rationale: Listening styles often clash in relationships. Empathetic listeners validate feelings; solution-givers want to fix; questioners seek understanding; presence-givers offer companionship. The classic 'I just want you to listen' vs. 'I'm trying to help' conflict stems from style mismatch.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different listening styles cause the most common relationship communication problem. The empathy-listener feels their solutions-giving partner doesn't care; the solutions-giver feels their empathy-listening partner is unhelpful. Ask: 'Do you want me to listen or help solve?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared listening styles mean you'll naturally respond to problems in ways that feel supportive. You'll give what you'd want to receive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When your partner shares a problem, what's your instinct? Do they appreciate your listening style? Have you ever asked what they need?

questions.text: How do I prefer you to communicate your needs to me?
choices: Written down so I can process
At a specific time when we can talk

therapeutic.rationale: Receiving partner needs requires its own skill. Direct receivers want clarity; context-seekers need reasoning; written-processors need time; scheduled-talkers need dedicated space. Communicating needs in the wrong format often means they go unmet even when our partner wants to help.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different need-receiving styles mean your partner's needs may not register in your preferred format. The direct receiver may miss gradual hints; the written-processor may not retain verbal requests. Adjust how you express needs to your partner's receiving style.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared need-receiving styles mean your requests will land as intended. You both process needs the same way.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you best receive information about what your partner needs? What format helps you actually act on their requests?

questions.text: What communication habit of yours means the most to me?
choices: Checking in on me during the day

therapeutic.rationale: Daily communication habits build relationship satisfaction over time. Check-ins show ongoing thinking; deep listening shows presence; open sharing shows vulnerability; remembered details show attention. Knowing which of your partner's habits means most helps you prioritize maintaining it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different valued habits reveal different communication priorities. Your partner may treasure something you do without realizing its importance. Name what matters most so they can keep doing it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared valued habits mean the same communication patterns create connection for you both. You're aligned on what matters in daily exchanges.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Which of your partner's communication habits do you most appreciate? Have you told them? What would be lost if they stopped doing it?
